repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Gift of Lorna D. Smith, donated as collected, beginning in 1966.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] Stokely Carmichael-Lorna D. Smith collection, M0170, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence, an inscribed book, and 15 scrapbooks filled with clippings from newspapers, magazines, circulars, folders, conference advertisements, and programs dating from July, 1964 to Nov. 1972. All of the items relate directly to Stokely Carmichael and to his work with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, and to his role in the Black Power movement, racial unrest, rioting in American cities (as represented by the Press).

The correspondence is mostly addressed to Mrs. Lorna Smith in reference to her work on the Mississippi Summer Project of 1964 or her later help with the efforts of SNCC, including 55 letters from Carmichael dating from December, 1964 to Nov. 1972. These are fairly personal in nature.

Included in the collection is Freedom Summer, inscribed by the author Sally Belfrage. Some of her letters to Mrs. Smith are also found in the collection, relating her opinions of the representation Carmichael received in the press.
Additions received on: Dec., 1967 - Seventh scrapbook, clips dating from

list.item: Mar. 1968 - Eighth scrapbook, clips dating Nov. 67 to
Apr. 30, 68 - Ninth scrapbook, clips dating Feb. 68 to Apr. 68
Nov. 1970 - 2 letters to Mrs. Smith, 7-8-70 from Carmichael, and 7-12-68 from Ukita.

scopecontent.p: SEE DONOR CARD FILE FOR FURTHER ADDITIONS.

chronitem.event: family moved to Harlem, New York and later to the East Bronx
graduated from the Bronx High School of Science
graduated from Howard University with a B.A. in Philosophy
field secretary of Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee

did.unittitle: clippings dating from July 1964 through July 1966.taken from all major newspapers and magazines as well as the following: The Salt Lake Tribune, Nat'l Guardian, Movement, Southern Courier, New Republic, I. F. Stone's Weekly, Memphis Press Scimitar, Commercial Appeal, Jackson Daily News, Jet

scopecontent.p: also envelopes from Carmichael, photo of marcher (June, 1966), circular letters, receipts

did.unittitle: clippings dating from July 1966 through August 1966.These are taken from a similar assortment of newspapers and magazines as well as: Kansas City Star, Christian Science Monitor, Harpers, CORE-LATOR, publications by the Santa Clara Valley Chapter Congress of Racial Equality.

scopecontent.p: Included are assorted items similar to those described above

did.unittitle: clippings dating from August 1966 through October.Additional sources: Commonweal, Mid-Valley News, Ebony, Village Voice, Liberation, New Student, Young Socialist, Los Angeles Free Press Sunday Ramparts, Fellowship. assorted ephemera

clippings dating from October 1966 through January 1967.Additional sources: A Radical Newspaper, Atlanta Black Paper (an abridgement printed in The Movement), Muhammed Speaks, The Progressive, The Independent Socialist. ephemera

clippings dating from February 1967 through March 1967.Additional sources: Spartan Daily, The Greensboro Daily News, Social Questions Dulletin, Together, News Notes (Central Comm. C.O.s), The Listener, Counterpart. assorted ephemera
clippings dating from April 1967 through August 1967.Additional sources: Fact, New Politics, Four Lights, League for Industrial Democracy, assorted ephemera.
clippings dating Jan.1969 -Dec.1969;including Mrs. Smith's certificate of membership in the D. A. R.
